meta.title: Lines and Angles - Exercise 6.2 (Short Answer Questions with Reasoning)

questions.question: For what value of $x + y$ in Fig. 6.4 will ABC be a line? Justify your answer.
questions.solution: For ABC to be a line, the sum of the adjacent angles $x$ and $y$ must be $180^\circ$ (Linear Pair Axiom).

questions.question: Can a triangle have all angles less than $60^\circ$? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution: If all angles are less than $60^\circ$, their sum will be less than $60^\circ \times 3 = 180^\circ$, which contradicts the angle sum property of a triangle.

questions.question: Can a triangle have two obtuse angles? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution: An obtuse angle is greater than $90^\circ$. If a triangle has two obtuse angles, their sum will be greater than $180^\circ$, which is not possible.

questions.question: Can a triangle have two right angles? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution: If a triangle has two right angles ($90^\circ$), their sum is $180^\circ$. The third angle would have to be $0^\circ$, which is not possible.

questions.question: Can a triangle have all angles more than $60^\circ$? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution: If all angles are greater than $60^\circ$, their sum will be greater than $180^\circ$, which contradicts the angle sum property.

questions.question: Can a triangle have all angles equal to $60^\circ$? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution: If all angles are $60^\circ$, their sum is $180^\circ$, which is valid. This is an equilateral triangle.

questions.question: Can a triangle have two acute angles? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution: A triangle must have at least two acute angles. For example, in a right triangle ($90^\circ, 45^\circ, 45^\circ$), there are two acute angles.

questions.question: Can a triangle have an exterior angle less than either of the interior opposite angles? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution: An exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two interior opposite angles. Therefore, it must be greater than each of the interior opposite angles.

questions.question: In Fig. 6.5, which of the two lines are parallel and why?
questions.solution:
In (i), the sum of interior angles on the same side of the transversal is $132^\circ + 48^\circ = 180^\circ$. Therefore, $l \parallel m$.
In (ii), the sum is $73^\circ + 106^\circ = 179^\circ \neq 180^\circ$. Therefore, $p$ and $q$ are not parallel.

questions.question: Two lines $l$ and $m$ are perpendicular to the same line $n$. Are $l$ and $m$ perpendicular to each other? Give reason for your answer.
questions.solution: If $l \perp n$ and $m \perp n$, then $\angle 1 = 90^\circ$ and $\angle 2 = 90^\circ$ (Corresponding angles). Since corresponding angles are equal, $l \parallel m$. They are not perpendicular.
